embeds.title: Goto
embeds.description:
Basic Skill / 1 :e_automaton: / The Automaton / Downfall

Draw 1 (2) card (cards).
**Encode.**
**Compile** - Next turn, draw 1 (2) card (cards).

messages.content: This is **the** card
the card yep

**Exhaust**.

exhaust non encodes

ah yes let me just delete the next 10 cards in my draw pile and staple some of them together
lets not forget the stapled ones go into ur hand
ah yes, Fetch+Seek+Encode+Scry+Exhaust

One of the more interesting cards in downfall. I think it's simultaneously very powerful, and reasonably well balanced due to it being a starter card. Barring dolly's mirror or other copying opportunities, you only get access to one, but it's really efficient card draw, and due to encode, you can make it even more efficient after stapling it to 2 other cards. As gangur pointed out, there are plenty of ways in automatons card pool to create additional copies of this mid combat if you can time your plays right. As is the case with several downfall characters, limited access to draw is meant to be one of automatons weaknesses, but with the right setup of cards, you can encode multiple gotos and break that balancing factor.

I would definitely draft more copies of this if I could, and it is a very good target for dolly's mirror once upgraded. The upgrade has to be one of the most ridiculous ones I can think of, drawing you an extra 3 cards assuming you play the completed function ASAP. As soon as I'm past gremlin nob, I really want to get this upgraded (I tend to like upgrading replicate at the starting campfire since it copies itself naturally and will get played nearly every time you draw it). I really don't think the upgraded version needs to increase the draw from the compile considering how good going from 1 card draw to 2 already is in the base affect.
if the compile effect was upgrade only and that was the only thing you get from upgrading it would probably still be a good card lol (id be interested in trying that version to see how it feels)
I do believe some kind of nerf is in order for goto, not necessarily a huge one, but the card is pretty insane right now, especially considering that it's a starter card.

Yeah I think it's in a unique balance position where it is strong, but it's not extremely problematic because of the fact that you can't easily get more copies. There is match game, and card duplication.
I like the idea of strong starter cards to balance out a weaker early game, but I do think downfall characters have too strong of a start of average.

Slime has tackle, and a huge hard hitting move like that helps a ton earlygame. Champ has shouts which just make the first couple of fights free. Auto has goto. You could debate hexa's float, since it is literally an unconditional unexhausting cantrip, but the effect it has does so little that I don't think it is too abusable.
And it isn't really strong in earlygame, so I think it is fine, as long as hexa doesn't have any other infinite cards (which they did in rewind, but it thankfully got changed)
Very off topic, but old rewind and float was an infinite. It was an uncommon and a starter card, so it was easier to get than the watcher infinite.
i suppose duped float is an infinite but it's a very slow one

old rewind for reference

https://discord.com/channels/669242017427226638/782759732023918592/1050592431067901962
But between this, champ's shouts, and slime starting with a tackle, I think there may be too many downfall characters with too op of a starter deck.
I would rather see it's upgrade be changed to make it 0 cost instead of increasing all draw by 1.

Twin slam is another starter card that is pretty outstanding, getting to double up on the socketed gems is very powerful if you can get the right ones. The starter cards for downfall do feel a little too strong on average in comparison to bash, survivor, dualcast, zap, and vigilance. Neutralize tends to be very solid, especially when upgraded (would definitely draft more copies if I could), and eruption is a wrath card (wrath is where most of watchers balance problems come from IMO). 

As for goto, I could definitely see the upgrade reducing the cost rather than increasing the draw, but that might require adding some extra card draw in their regular card pool to compensate. Ideally, a starter card should introduce the mechanics of the character, maybe support certain synergy packages, and be around the power level of a common. While goto is very strong in the lategame, it's not that good early on when you don't have enough energy to afford spending it on card draw, and it is an airy skill going into gremlin nob, tri sentries, gremlin gang and slime gang.
Honestly I don't think auto should have much draw, functions are basically 3 cards glued together so that should be more than enough to help for consistency.
As for twin slam, I see it in the same vein as float. It doesn't really have the tools necessary to be used to its full potential until late game, which I think is fine for a starter card.
Goto though is good in early game and gets absolutely insane in late game
I understand why twin slam would be duplicated, since you're also duplicating the gems in it, but I think no other starter card should be strong enough to where you would almost always duplicate it
and the amount of times that I don't dupe goto is rare, last time that I didn't was probably when hardcode existed
hardcode btw
It basically permanently adds a function to your deck (and removes all the individual cards from it and itself)
